title: Do soldiers ever kill fellow soldiers during battle? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, most definitely. I will attach below one story collected from the Japanese newspaper “Asahi Shimbun”. During the 80s, they had a serialization where they collected thousands of stories from Japanese veterans and civilians detailing their experiences during the war, This is one of them  Stabbing a Wounded Friend I would like to write about my friend "K", now passed away. At the end of the Pacific War, he was a soldier in the Phillipine Battlefront. Pursued by superior American forces, his company was wandering among the jungles of Luzon. The Manila Defense Headquarters had already retreated deep into the mountains. Heading in that direction, his company had lost a third of its men. Many were wounded. Passing through the jungle, exposed to the continuous rain and the barrage of gunfire from the American forces, they had to cross over a bald mountain. It was impossible to climb with the wounded. Among the wounded was "M", who was a close friend of "K". He had been shot through the thigh, and the lower half of his body had already turned purple, like a corpse. There were many others who were unable to move and could only wait for death. Those who pleaded, "Take us with you", were told, "We'll come back to get you," and the company left, climbing the mountain under the cover of night. Towards dawn, the company finally reached a spot with trees, near the summit. There they made their headquarters. It was then that "K," along with two other soldiers, received the callous order of the company commander. They were told to go down and kill off any wounded men who might still be alive. According to the commander, if any wounded were taken prisoner, they could leak information about the movements of the Japanese forces."K" and the others resisted these order. Yet on being told it was necessary to save their own lives, there was nothing they could do. Waiting for night to fall, they went back down to the place where they had left the wounded. A few men were still alive. "M" was among them."You came back for us after all," "M" wept with gratitude. Unable to kill him, "K" engaged in a rambling conversation. But the enemy could come at any time, so "K" pulled his sword out in the dark and frantically stabbed "M". "K" said no matter how many years had passed since the War's end, he was unable to rid himself of the heavy burden on his heart. Nakayama Juntarou, sixty-six (m.)self-employed, Tokyo

During the Vietnam war, many U.S. soldiers killed their own officers with a fragmentation grenade and the phenomenon became known as “fragging”. Gradually, the term fragging was used to refer to cases of servicemen deliberately killing each other, regardless of the weapon used[1]. The officers killed were often either gung-ho, reckless with the lives of his men or incompetent and getting their men into unnecessary danger. It also happened in other armies under different circumstances. In the book “D-Day: The battle for Normandy”, author Antony Beevor tells of one incident that an American pilot witnessed: Glider infantrymen were extremely vulnerable at this moment if within range of German positions. ‘Upon landing,’ wrote one pilot, ‘we discovered the source of the ground fire which nearly got me. It turned out to be a bunker containing about a dozen conscripted Polish soldiers with one German in charge. After the glider infantrymen from several gliders, including ours, directed a hail of rifle-fire at the bunker, the resistance ceased. There was silence in the bunker, and then a single shot. Then there were shouts and laughter, and these Poles emerged with their hands held high. They weren’t about to fight the Americans so they simply shot the Kraut sergeant.’ A Soviet veteran of the battle of Stalingrad described what he saw at a Volga river crossing[2] : I saw it with my own eyes. A one and a half ton truck “GAZ AA” approached the river crossing […] with a captain in the cab and five soldiers in its body. The captain came out of the cab and proceeded: “Get out of the way; we need to get on the ferry!” But the ferry was being loaded with the wounded at that moment, the Luftwaffe could attack any moment, but the captain still insisted. He was asked to step aside. But he pulled out his pistol and said: “I’m going to shoot!” And surely he would have. So, he was shot dead and that was it! The soldiers turned around and drove off to their unit. Well, what can you say about that? It had to be done... Footnotes[1] Duc Quyen's answer to Do soldiers ever "frag" or kill their officers? Why?[2] Orlov Nikolai Vasilievich

Yes. You just have to ask why they do. One is known as Friendly Fire. List of friendly fire incidents - Wikipedia Another is known as “Fragging.” Fragging - Wikipedia Finally, there is Battlefield Euthanasia, better known as Mercy Killing. For this one, I don’t have a simple link to post so you can read it all at once. Instead, do a search for “military mercy killing” and see if it doesn’t bring up several pages of incidents and debates about whether this is a mercy killing or a war crime. Personally, I find this the worst. You know they are dying, possibly in sever pain, but the question can nag at you long after the person is gone. Even if you know you saved them pain, you still killed someone who wasn’t hostile. In fact, in another situation, they might have lived. Do you leave them to die alone? Do you stay with them, if you can, so they don’t die alone? OR do you end it for them? Watching anyone non-hostile die is painful. But, to know you are responsible is worse. It can really eat at you knowing that you had to act simply because fate rolled the dice to let it happen this way. The IFs that eat at you can drive you crazy. It’s not even easy to write this without wanting to use offensive language over how messed up it is. Of course, there is another messed up aspect of friendly fire. There is an accepted amount of it allowed. Somehow, “Hey, it’s cool. It’s Friendly Fire” just doesn’t fit in a normal vocabulary. You know?

There are two kinds of situations when soldiers kill fellow soldiers.   The first is by friendly fire which by definition is not very friendly.  This is accidental and happens in just about every war.  I may be wrong about this but I believe that a significant portion of the American casualties in the First Gulf War were from friendlly fire. The second is actual murder under the cover of battle.  This is common enough that there is an actual term for it - Fragging. It is more common in draft armies (like the US Army in the Vietnam War) that in all volunteer armies like the current US Army.   Is it common - no.  I think that the combination of the will and opportunity are fairly rare.  Does it ever happen (as your question asks) yes.

If this happens in your unit, and it wasn’t by accident, then you know that you serve in a really shitty military. Your fellow soldier is your brother. Period. Of course, there are those rare cases where a soldier acts out and starts doing crazy things, but there are other ways to deal with it than killing the guy. You can disable a person by shooting them in the leg, for example. If it really comes down to killing or wounding a comrade, it’s the leader’s job to do that. They are in charge of keeping the discipline which is necessary to accomplish the mission. Therefore, it’s also their responsibility to enforce this discipline. Soldiers, on the other hand, never kill their buddies.

Yes, and this is known as “fragging”. Enlisted men or junior officers are known to have murdered higher officers whom they consider incompetent, foolhardy, psychopatic, tyrannical or overtlly ambitious without caring the men’s lives. When a superior officer sends a distrusted, disgruntled or disliked subordinate to a mission he calculates he won’t survive, this is known as “Uriah gambit”. Outright murders between peers do also happen, and they are usually due to personal issues, drug or gambling debts, adultery or drunken brawls.

Yes it happens. Albert(not his real name) a neighbour of my Grandfathers was in the same regiment as Winston Churchill and he told me this . When Winston Churchill left the Admiralty in disgrace after the disastrous Dardenells campaign he went to the western front. When Churchill arrived to take charge of the regiment they were stationed in a quiet sector (live and let live) having recently taken quite a few casualties. Churchill being a very gung ho officer and out to rehabilitate his reputation , was finding new ways of getting them killed as they saw it . It was decided amongst their company’s rank and file that during the next attack he led, they would “shoot the Bastard” Alberts words. Looking back its a good job they never got the chance as the Second World War might have ended differently. Just how many hated officers and NCOs were intentionally killed in the heat of battle by an aggrieved soldier or soldiers will never be known.

I think you’re referring to friendly fire incidents. The fog of war inevitably leads to such accidents. In The Battle of Karánsebes, the Austrian Army accidentally fought against itself at night, causing 10,000 casualties. During the invasion of the Aleutians, US and Canadian troops captured a deserted enemy base but not before shooting at each other by mistake, resulting in fatalities. When WW2 in the Pacific ended, US ships started shooting rounds into the sky in celebration. IIRC over 20 American servicemen were killed. I’m sure there are plenty of other examples abounding in war. You play enough paintball and you’ll realize getting shot by your own side when you’re in the front line happens too often.

Very rarely but yes. Read about the last year or two in Vietnam. But most often those killed would be accidental. They used to say that around 10–15% or more in bigger battles are killed by friendly fire. Think we even had a couple of 3 star Generals in WWII killed by accident, while up near the front. Mortars and artillery can fall short, bombers can be off by a few hundred yards. jungles make it sometimes impossible to quickly identify the bad guys from the good guys. Cruise missiles aren’t perfect.

By accident? Yes. Unfortunately it happens quite often, and is one of the inherent risks of combat. There are even terms for it: “Blue on blue” or “fratricide”. These incidents are treated as accidents, and bring no criminal penalties On purpose? Yes it does happen, but not that often. And those incidents are treated as crimes.

In the Vietnam War, American soldiers did sometimes ‘accidentally’ shoot reckless officers, those a little too gung ho with the lives of their men. And then of course there is the every present danger of death by friendly fire. This occurs more often than anyone cares to think about.
My father did in WWII. One of his buddies was screaming with his face and front of his head gone. My dad quickly shot him in what was left.

Those who are directly attributed to causing the death of a fellow soldier are liable under the UCMJ for these charges: Article 118 - Murder or Article 119 - Manslaughter. This is determined by preliminary investigation. It may also be determined that the soldier was faultless in this act and not be charged or prosecuted.
A famous example for ther western world is the vietnam war. Seemingly incompetent superiours were killed by friendly granades, there term is “Fragging”. Fragging - Wikipedia
Unfortunately yes, however majority is accidental blue on blue during ambushes etc. Where the soldier was not thinking quick enough or in the right mindset
